reviews.review_msg: Lots of very dense cogs readings that are hard to understand. This course was a tough one to get through. But it was fair with clear marking requirements. There was a group project. I got an amazing group however (your mileage may vary on that part). She was always very quick to respond to emails and answer any questions as well.

In the group project, two of us did most of the work. We lost a lot of points because of this. This was very unfair to those of us who put in the work. I wish the textbook was used, it would have made studying easier.

If you catch a marking mistake, she won't even bother replying to your email. This has been my least engaging course at SFU of my three years. She records all lectures, but she bothered posting for weeks 1, 2, and 8. Which is quite deceiving because that's the drop deadline. I wish I waited for another prof to teach this course.

COGS 200 with Prof Grant is fun and fairly involved. She covers a lot of material in the course with plenty of mandatory readings that can be quite time consuming. For a second-year level course it is not difficult but does demand a lot of time to be successful in. Prof. Grant is a solid lecturer and cares about the students.
Very harsh grader with very vague instructions. He is a very nice man but as a prof he is not good. Pretty good but boring lectures, extremely nitpicky and unfair grading.

He is not good at teaching. He doesn't even stick by his own grading criteria and it's really difficult to know what he is expecting. When students inevitably struggle he is not caring enough to be helpful.
far from clear presentations and slides, can't explain concepts clearly but expects students to be able to do that.
